content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Elizabeth Carlsen: I was born in Massachusetts, in a small town in New England, and I grew up in a close-knit family. My parents were both very involved in my life—my father worked as a teacher, and my mother was a nurse. We weren't wealthy, but we had a comfortable life, and I always felt supported. I remember my mother reading to me every night, and my father encouraging me to ask questions about everything. I went to a public school, and I was pretty lucky to have some amazing teachers who really inspired me. I was always interested in literature and social issues, which probably explains why I ended up leaning more towards liberal politics as I grew older. I went to college in Boston, where I met my husband, and we've been together ever since. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I feel like I've been lucky to have a stable family, a good education, and a career that I enjoy. I'm still figuring out what the next chapter will bring, but I'm grateful for where I am.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. I was in my second year of college, studying English literature, and I had the opportunity to take a summer internship with a nonprofit that worked with immigrant families in Boston. I had always been interested in social justice, but that experience opened my eyes to the real struggles people face when they come to this country seeking a better life. I remember one particular family—parents who had left their home country under difficult circumstances, trying to give their children a chance they didn't have. I saw how language barriers, lack of resources, and systemic challenges affected their daily lives. That summer, I realized that I wanted to use my skills not just for personal fulfillment, but to help others. It was then that I decided to pursue a career in community advocacy, even though I had initially thought I would go into teaching or writing. That choice led me to meet my husband, who was working with the same organization at the time, and it ultimately shaped the kind of person I am today—someone who believes in using her voice and her education to make a difference in her community.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, but one that felt inevitable once I had that experience. I remember sitting in my dorm room that summer, thinking about everything I had seen and how it contrasted with my own life. I had always been lucky, and I realized I didn't want to just live a comfortable life—I wanted to do something that mattered. I remember telling my parents that night, and my mother just looked at me and said, 'If you're going to do this, you have to be ready to fight for it.' That stuck with me. It wasn't just about changing my career path; it was about changing how I saw myself and my role in the world. I didn't just choose advocacy—I chose to be someone who would stand up for others, even when it was hard.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Absolutely. I think the internship program itself was a lifeline for me—it gave me the opportunity to step outside my academic bubble and see the world through someone else's eyes. But I also think my parents played a role in helping me feel confident enough to make that choice. My mother, in particular, had always been a strong advocate for others in her work as a nurse, and she modeled that kind of compassion and courage for me. I also remember talking to a mentor at the nonprofit, a woman named Maria, who had come to the U.S. as a teenager and built a life here through sheer determination. She was the one who encouraged me to see my education not just as a personal achievement, but as a tool I could use to help others. Without that support system—both personal and professional—I don't think I would have had the clarity or the courage to take that step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Yes, I have a partner—my husband, Daniel. We met during that summer internship I told you about, working with the same nonprofit. He was a community organizer at the time, and we bonded over our shared passion for social justice. We got married a few years later, after we both finished our graduate studies. We've been together for over a decade now, and we have two children—Emma, who's eight, and Liam, who's five. They're both in public school, just like I was, and I try to instill in them the same values my parents gave me: curiosity, kindness, and a sense of responsibility to others. Daniel and I both work full time, but we make it a priority to be present for our kids. We live in Cambridge now, not too far from where I grew up, and I love that our kids are growing up in a city that's both vibrant and full of opportunities. It's not always easy balancing work and family life, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my life. It's interesting to look back and see how my childhood, education, and early experiences shaped the person I am today. The internship that changed my path was a pivotal moment, and thinking about it now, I realize how much it defined my values and career. It's also humbling to think about the people who supported me along the way—my parents, my husband, and the mentors who believed in me. Being asked about my family now, especially my children, reminded me how much I want to pass on the same values and sense of purpose that were instilled in me. It's a full circle moment, and I'm grateful for the journey that brought me here.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Elizabeth Carlsen: My immediate family includes my parents, John and Maria Carlsen, and my younger sister, Sophia. My parents are still very much a part of my life, and we talk often—especially about the kids. My father, John, is retired now after teaching high school for over thirty years, and he still volunteers at the community center where I used to work. My mother, Maria, is still working part-time as a nurse, and she's always been my biggest supporter. She's the one who encouraged me to take that internship, and I think she's proud of the path I've chosen. My sister, Sophia, is a few years younger than me, and she's a graphic designer in Boston. We're close, even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like. She's always been more of a free spirit than I am, but I admire her creativity and her willingness to take risks. Our family has always been close, and I think that's one of the reasons I feel so grounded in my own life and choices.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been incredibly important to me over the years. One of them is Maria, the mentor I mentioned earlier at the nonprofit—she's like a second mother to me. She's been a constant source of wisdom and encouragement, especially when I was starting out in advocacy work. Then there's my best friend, Sarah, who I met in college. She's a social worker now, and we've been through a lot together. We've supported each other through career changes, personal struggles, and just the everyday ups and downs of life. I also have a few close coworkers at the community center where I volunteer part-time—people who understand the mission I'm passionate about and who keep me grounded. They're not just colleagues; they're friends who challenge me to be better and remind me why I do what I do. I think having that network of people who believe in me and in the work we're doing is what keeps me going, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Elizabeth Carlsen: I live in a neighborhood in Cambridge that feels like a mix of old and new—historic buildings standing alongside modern apartments, and a lot of diversity in both people and ideas. It's a walkable area, which I love, especially with the kids. We're close to the Harvard campus, which gives the neighborhood a kind of academic energy, but it's also very community-focused. There's a big park near our house where the kids play, and it's not uncommon to see families from all over the world hanging out there. I think that's one of the things I love most about Cambridge—it's a place where different cultures and perspectives coexist, and it's reflected in the schools, the restaurants, and even the way people talk to each other. It's not perfect, of course, and there are challenges like rising housing costs, but overall, it's a place that feels alive and full of possibility. I like that my kids are growing up here, surrounded by people who are working to make the world a better place, just like I did.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. Cambridge has a strong sense of community, and I think that plays a big role in making the neighborhood feel secure. I know a lot of the people who live around us, and there's a general sense of looking out for one another. That said, like any urban area, there are parts of the city that feel less safe, especially at night or in certain areas. But for our part, we're in a quiet, family-friendly section of town, and I feel confident letting the kids play outside or walk to school. I think safety is also about how you engage with your community—knowing your neighbors, being involved in local initiatives, and feeling like your voice matters. That sense of belonging and connection is what makes me feel safe, not just the physical environment itself.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Elizabeth Carlsen: Living here has been mostly positive, though it's not without its challenges. One of the things I love most is the sense of community—there are so many people who are engaged in local causes, from neighborhood clean-ups to supporting small businesses. It's inspiring to see that kind of collective effort. That said, the cost of living here is definitely a strain. We're lucky to have a stable income, but I know a lot of people in our neighborhood are struggling to afford housing or even basic necessities. It's something I think about often, especially as I work in community advocacy. I want to make sure that the kind of support I received growing up is available to others, no matter where they live. On a more personal level, I appreciate the cultural richness of the area. We've had so many interesting conversations with our neighbors, and the kids have been exposed to so many different traditions and languages. It's a reminder that the world is bigger than we sometimes realize, and that's something I hope they carry with them as they grow up.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about my husband, children, and parents reminded me of the importance of family and the values we pass down. It also made me think about how much my neighborhood in Cambridge has influenced my perspective on community, safety, and the challenges we face together. I feel grateful to live in a place where there's a strong sense of belonging, even though it's not without its struggles. It's comforting to know that the same sense of community that supported me growing up is still alive here, and I hope to continue being a part of it for my children and for others who need it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Elizabeth Carlsen: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I work full time at a nonprofit that focuses on immigrant and refugee integration, so my days are often spent meeting with clients, organizing community events, and collaborating with other organizations. Mondays are usually the busiest, with meetings and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about direct service—meeting with families, helping them navigate resources, and sometimes even translating for those who don't speak English well. Thursdays are often a mix of both, and I try to reserve Fridays for something a bit more relaxed, like picking up the kids from school or going to the park. On weekends, we usually have family time—Sunday mornings are for church, and then we have a big family lunch. Daniel and I also try to take the kids to a museum or a cultural event once a month. It's a busy life, but I love the balance between work and family. I think it's important to be present for both, even when it's exhausting. There are days when I feel like I'm running on a treadmill, but I remind myself that this is the life I chose—one that's meaningful, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I work full time at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on supporting immigrant and refugee families in integrating into local life. My role is a mix of direct service and program coordination—I spend a lot of time meeting with families, helping them access essential resources like housing, healthcare, and education, and also work with local government and other nonprofits to create policies that better serve these communities. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., though I often stay late when there are meetings or events to plan. The work can be emotionally demanding, especially when I hear stories of people who've faced incredible hardship just to be here, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I find that my job gives me a sense of purpose that I didn't always have before, and I feel like I'm making a real difference, even if it's just one person at a time. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Outside of work and family, I have a few other routines that keep me grounded. I try to make time for exercise, usually going for a run or a yoga class a few times a week. It's not always easy with the kids and the job, but I find it helps me manage stress and stay focused. I also have a small garden in our backyard where I grow herbs and some vegetables. It's a small thing, but it gives me a sense of peace and connection to the earth. I also enjoy reading—mostly fiction, though I do read some nonfiction related to my work. I think it's important to keep learning and to let my mind wander, even if just for a little while. And of course, I try to cook at home as much as possible. Daniel and I both love food, and we enjoy experimenting with different cuisines, especially ones from the cultures represented in our neighborhood. It's a way for us to bring people together, and it's something I hope our kids will carry with them too.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Elizabeth Carlsen: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing a short meditation before getting the kids ready, and it's been a game-changer for my focus and patience. It's funny, because I used to think of mindfulness as something 'new age' or only for people with a lot of time, but now I see it as a necessary tool for someone like me who juggles so many responsibilities. I also started setting aside 15 minutes each evening to journal about my day—just a few thoughts, things I'm grateful for, or even frustrations I want to process. It's helped me reflect more deeply on my work and my family life, and I've noticed I'm more present with the kids now. I think these small changes, while not earth-shattering, have made a real difference in how I approach each day. It's a reminder that even in the busiest of lives, there's room to pause and take care of yourself—something I didn't always prioritize before.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Elizabeth Carlsen: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts early—usually around 7 a.m. They both have breakfast with us, and then they head off to school. Emma is in third grade, and Liam is in kindergarten. Their school day is pretty structured: morning classes, recess, lunch, and then some kind of enrichment activity in the afternoon. Emma has been participating in a coding club, which she loves, and Liam is in a soccer program. After school, they come home, have a snack, and then we usually have some downtime before dinner. On some days, especially when they have after-school activities, we pick them up and go straight to the activity, but on other days, they have free time to play or do homework. I try to make sure they have time to be creative, whether it's drawing, building with Legos, or just talking about their day. We also have family dinners most nights, which is something I really value. It's a chance for us to connect, share stories, and just be together. I know it's not perfect—some days are more chaotic than others—but I think these routines give them a sense of stability, which is important for kids.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about my family and neighborhood reminded me of the importance of community, safety, and the values we pass down. It also made me think about the challenges of living in a place like Cambridge, where the cost of living is high, but the sense of belonging is strong. I feel grateful to live in a place where there's a strong sense of community, even though it's not without its struggles. It's comforting to know that the same sense of community that supported me growing up is still alive here, and I hope to continue being a part of it for my children and for others who need it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Elizabeth Carlsen: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I wouldn't call myself a health nut. I try to stay active with my runs and yoga, and I make an effort to eat well, but there are definitely days when I slip up—like when I'm too busy or stressed and end up grabbing a coffee and a muffin on the way to work. I do have some chronic issues, like mild anxiety, which I manage through mindfulness and talking to my therapist. I also have a history of migraines, which can be pretty disruptive, but I've learned to recognize the triggers and take steps to prevent them. Overall, I think I'm pretty healthy, but I'm always working on being better. I want to be around for my kids for a long time, so I take their health seriously, and I try to model that for them. It's not always easy, but I think it's worth it.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Elizabeth Carlsen: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a support system—my husband, my kids, and even my friends who encourage me to take care of myself. When I'm in a routine, like running a few times a week or cooking meals at home, it feels more manageable. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling of work, family, and personal time. There are days when I feel like I'm stretched thin, and I forget to prioritize my own well-being. I think the biggest challenge is finding that balance, especially when I'm so focused on making sure my kids are happy and healthy. I've learned that small habits—like taking a walk during my lunch break or making time for a few deep breaths in the morning—can make a big difference, but it's not always easy to remember to do them. I'm still learning, and I hope I can keep improving.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Elizabeth Carlsen: In the past two years, I had a flare-up of my migraines that was more severe than usual. It started around the time I was leading a major initiative at work to expand our services to more families in the community. The stress was intense, and I didn't realize how much it was affecting my body until I ended up in the doctor's office with a migraine that lasted for three days. I had to take a few days off work, which was hard because I felt like I was letting the team down. But it was a wake-up call—I realized I needed to be more proactive about managing my stress and my health. Since then, I've been working with my therapist more regularly and have started setting clearer boundaries between work and home life. I also began seeing a chiropractor for some of the tension I was carrying in my neck and shoulders, which has helped a lot. It's been a process, but I feel more in control now, and I'm grateful for the reminder that taking care of myself isn't just important—it's necessary.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Honestly, there were moments when my health issues did make things more difficult, especially during that intense period with the migraine flare-up. I remember one day when I was so exhausted and in pain that I had to cancel a meeting with a family we were trying to help. It was hard not being able to be there for them, and I felt guilty about it. But what I realized was that taking care of myself isn't just about being present for others—it's about being able to show up for them in a way that's sustainable. Since then, I've been more intentional about saying no when I need to, and I've learned to ask for help when I can't do everything on my own. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that my health is just as important as my work or my family. If I'm not well, I can't be the best version of myself for anyone. That's something I want my kids to understand too—taking care of your body and mind is a form of love, not just for yourself, but for the people who depend on you.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Elizabeth Carlsen: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel incredibly grateful and grounded, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping up. The work I do has been both fulfilling and exhausting, especially with the ongoing challenges in our community. I've seen more families struggling than ever before, and it's weighed on me in ways I didn't expect. At the same time, I've also felt a deep sense of connection with my family, especially with my kids. They've grown so much, and watching them navigate school, friendships, and their own little challenges has been both heartwarming and humbling. I've also been trying to be more present in my own life, whether it's through mindfulness, journaling, or just taking a few minutes to breathe. I think I've learned that life isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when it's hard. And I'm trying to do that, every day.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being are intertwined with the rest of my life. It's easy to forget to take care of myself when I'm so focused on work, family, and the needs of others, but I've come to realize that my health isn't just a personal issue—it's the foundation that allows me to be present for the people I love and the work I care about. The recent changes I've made, like incorporating mindfulness and journaling into my routine, have helped me feel more balanced and grounded. I'm learning that small, consistent habits can make a big difference, and I'm grateful for the reminder that taking care of myself is not a luxury, but a necessity. It's also humbling to think about how my health challenges have affected my ability to show up for others, and how important it is to set boundaries and ask for help when needed. I hope that by modeling this for my children, I'm teaching them that self-care is a form of love and responsibility, not just for ourselves, but for everyone around us.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I think I've struggled with anxiety in the past, especially during times when I felt overwhelmed by work or personal responsibilities. It's something I didn't always talk about openly, but I've come to realize that it's a part of me, just like anyone else's struggles. I used to feel like I had to be strong all the time, like showing vulnerability was a weakness. But over the years, I've learned that asking for help is a sign of strength, not a flaw. I started seeing a therapist a few years ago, and that's been incredibly helpful. It's allowed me to process my thoughts and emotions in a healthier way, and it's also helped me understand that it's okay to not be okay all the time. I think the hardest part is still learning to be kind to myself when I'm feeling down, but I'm getting better at it. I want my kids to know that it's okay to feel anxious or sad sometimes, and that it's important to take care of your mental health just like you take care of your physical health. I'm still on this journey, but I'm grateful for the support I've received and the progress I've made.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Elizabeth Carlsen: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and growth. Daniel has been doing well at work, though he's been juggling more responsibilities lately with his team at the community center. He's been under a lot of pressure, but he's learning to manage it better, partly because he's seen me try to do the same. Our kids have been adjusting to the changes in their routines, especially with school being more demanding as they get older. Emma, in particular, has been dealing with some social pressures at school, which has been tough to watch. I've had to have some really honest conversations with her about kindness, standing up for herself, and knowing when to ask for help. Liam, on the other hand, has been more resilient—he just seems to roll with whatever comes his way. As a family, we've been trying to make time for each other, even when it's hard. We've started having weekly family game nights, which have been a nice way to reconnect and just laugh together. It's not perfect, but I think we're all learning how to support each other better, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: For me, religion has always been an important part of my life, though I wouldn't say it's the only thing that defines me. I was raised Catholic, and my parents made sure that faith was woven into our daily lives—whether through Sunday Mass, family prayers before meals, or the values we were taught about kindness, forgiveness, and service to others. Even now, as an adult, I find comfort in my faith, especially during difficult times. It's not just about going to church or following rituals; it's about the sense of community and belonging that comes with being part of a faith tradition. I've always believed that faith is about connecting with something bigger than yourself, and that has guided me in both my personal and professional life. I try to live by the teachings I was raised with—treating others with compassion, standing up for what's right, and being grateful for the blessings I have. My children were baptized and attend Sunday school, and I hope they grow up with the same sense of purpose and connection that I've had. Of course, I know that not everyone shares my beliefs, and I respect that. But for me, faith is a grounding force, and I'm grateful for the role it has played in shaping who I am.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Elizabeth Carlsen: I actually don't use social media very much, and I think that's something I've come to peace with. I used to be on Facebook more regularly, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, but over the years, I've found that it can be more of a distraction than a connection. I've noticed that the more I scroll, the more I compare my life to others, and that doesn't always feel good. I've also been conscious of how social media can sometimes spread misinformation or create division, especially around political issues, which is something I care deeply about. Instead of spending time on platforms, I prefer to connect in person—whether it's through my neighborhood group meetings, family dinners, or even just a coffee with a friend. I do follow a few accounts related to my work, like organizations that focus on immigrant rights or mental health advocacy, but I keep it minimal. I think it's important to be present in the real world, and I've found that limiting my screen time helps me do that. My kids don't use social media yet, and I'm grateful for that—I want them to grow up with a strong sense of self and the ability to engage with the world in a meaningful way, not just through a screen.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Honestly, I don't find myself turning to social media for support during tough times. I've always leaned on my family, friends, and my faith for that kind of comfort. When things get overwhelming, I know I can call my mother or my husband, or even just sit with my kids and talk through whatever's on my mind. I think there's something about face-to-face connection that social media can't really replace. That said, I do recognize that for some people, those platforms can be a lifeline—especially if they're going through something and don't have a strong support system. I just know that for me, the real connections are the ones that matter most. I'm not saying social media has no place, but I think it's important to be intentional about how we use it and what we take from it.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and mental well-being are intertwined with the rest of my life. It's easy to push through pain or anxiety when I'm focused on work and family, but I've come to realize that neglecting my own health only makes things harder in the long run. The migraine flare-up was a wake-up call—I realized that I can't be there for others if I'm not taking care of myself first. It's also been humbling to acknowledge that I've struggled with anxiety, especially in times of stress. I used to think that showing vulnerability was a weakness, but I've learned that asking for help and being open about my struggles is actually a form of strength. I'm still learning how to be kinder to myself when I'm not feeling my best, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made. These reflections have also made me more aware of how my mental health affects my family—especially my kids. I want them to understand that it's okay to feel anxious or sad sometimes, and that taking care of your mind is just as important as taking care of your body. I hope that by modeling this for them, I'm helping them build a healthier relationship with their own well-being.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Elizabeth Carlsen: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have fluctuated, especially with the increased demands at work and the challenges of raising two kids in a high-cost area like Cambridge. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, trying to balance everything without burning out. But I've been working on my emotional coping strategies, and it's been a process. I've started setting clearer boundaries between work and home life, which has helped me feel more in control. I also find that talking through my feelings with my husband or my therapist has made a big difference. I've learned to recognize when I'm feeling overwhelmed and to take a step back, whether that means going for a walk, journaling, or just sitting quietly for a few minutes. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be more intentional about how I manage my emotions. I think the biggest shift has been realizing that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. I hope that by modeling this for my kids, I'm teaching them that it's okay to feel stressed or worried sometimes, and that there are healthy ways to cope with those feelings.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Last month, our biggest expenses were housing, childcare, and groceries. Rent is always the largest chunk of our budget—Cambridge is expensive, and even though we're in a more affordable part of the city, it still takes up about a third of our income. Childcare is another major cost, especially since we both work full time. We use a combination of in-home care and after-school programs, which adds up quickly. Groceries are also a significant expense, especially since we try to eat healthy and support local businesses. We also have some regular bills like car payments, insurance, and utilities. It's a tight budget, but we've learned to prioritize what matters most—like making sure the kids have what they need and that we can still contribute to our community through volunteering and advocacy work. I think the biggest challenge is balancing all of that while still trying to save for the future, like college funds for the kids or emergency savings. It's not always easy, but we've gotten pretty good at making it work.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Last month, our household spent roughly around $6,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. It was partly because we had a few unexpected expenses—like a new car tire that needed replacing and a last-minute family trip to visit my parents for my father's birthday. Normally, we spend about $5,800 to $6,000 a month, with the majority going toward rent, childcare, and groceries. We also have regular expenses like car insurance, utilities, and a few subscription services for streaming and online learning tools for the kids. I've been trying to track our spending more carefully, especially with the rising cost of living here. It's a balancing act, but we've learned to prioritize what's essential and cut back on things that aren't. For example, we've reduced our dining out and opted for more home-cooked meals, which has helped a bit. I also try to remind myself that while it's not always easy, we're fortunate to have stable incomes and a strong support system. It's not about luxury—it's about making sure we can provide for our family and still give back to the community we're a part of.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Elizabeth Carlsen: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in a building that's been around for a few decades, and while it's not the most modern, it's comfortable and well-maintained. Renting has always made more sense for us, especially with the way our lives have evolved—both Daniel and I work full time, and with the kids in school, we need flexibility. We're in a part of Cambridge that's still affordable compared to some of the other neighborhoods, but it's clear that housing is a challenge for a lot of people here. I know several families in our community who are struggling to find stable housing, and it's something I think about often in my work. Renting allows us to stay rooted in this neighborhood without the long-term commitment of homeownership, and I feel like it's the right choice for our family right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Elizabeth Carlsen: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the kids' schedules. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up quite a bit, and we also had to pay for more winter clothes for the kids. Then, when school started again in the fall, we had to budget for after-school programs and extracurricular activities, which added to our monthly expenses. On the other hand, during the summer, we spent less on childcare since the kids were out of school, but we had higher costs for things like summer camps and family trips. Holidays also bring their own set of expenses—like gift-giving, holiday meals, and sometimes even travel. One thing that's stayed pretty consistent is our rent and utilities, but I've noticed that the cost of groceries has gone up slightly over the year, which is something I've been trying to manage by planning meals more carefully and buying in bulk when possible. It's all part of the rhythm of life, and while it can be stressful at times, I've learned to adapt and find ways to make it work.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply intertwined my family's well-being is with my own mental and emotional health. It's been a journey to recognize that my anxiety and stress don't just affect me—they ripple out to my children, my husband, and even my parents. I've come to understand that being open about my struggles, whether it's with my therapist, my husband, or even my kids, is not a sign of weakness but of strength. It's also made me more aware of how I want my children to view mental health—less as something to hide and more as something to care for with the same attention as their physical health. I'm grateful for the support I've received from my family and friends, and I hope that by modeling vulnerability and resilience, I'm helping my kids build a healthier relationship with their own emotions and challenges.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. It's not always easy with our budget, but I've made it a priority to set aside money for emergencies, college funds for the kids, and even for little things like family trips or unexpected expenses. I think the key for us has been being intentional about it—automating transfers to our savings account so we don't forget, and also being mindful of where our money goes. I know that not everyone has the luxury of saving, and I see it in the community we work with—so many families are just trying to get by, and that's why I feel so strongly about advocating for better financial support systems. For us, saving is less about accumulating wealth and more about having a safety net, so we can keep showing up for each other and for the people we serve. It's a small step, but it's one that gives me peace of mind.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Elizabeth Carlsen: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a big purchase like a home. We've been focusing on building an emergency fund, which has been especially important given the rising costs of living here and the unpredictable nature of our work in community advocacy. I also contribute to college savings accounts for Emma and Liam, even if it's just a small amount each month. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared so that we can keep showing up for each other and for the people we serve. I know how precarious life can be, especially for the families we work with, and I want my kids to grow up knowing that planning for the future is just as important as living in the moment. It's a balance, but one I'm committed to maintaining.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Carlsen: My occupation is as a Community Advocate and Program Coordinator at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on supporting immigrant and refugee families in integrating into local life. In this role, I spend a lot of time meeting with families, helping them access essential resources like housing, healthcare, and education, and also work with local government and other nonprofits to create policies that better serve these communities. The most important activities or duties include direct client services, where I listen to their stories and help them navigate the complex systems they often encounter. I also organize community events, like cultural festivals and workshops, to bring people together and foster a sense of belonging. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing the impact of our work—whether it's a family finding stable housing, a child enrolling in school, or a community member feeling more connected to their new home. It's not always easy, especially when I hear stories of people who've faced incredible hardship just to be here, but I find that the work gives me a deep sense of purpose. I think what drives me most is the belief that everyone deserves a chance to thrive, and I want to be part of creating a world where that's possible for all.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Elizabeth Carlsen: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and the projects we're working on. There are weeks when I'm in the office from early morning until late evening, especially when we're launching a new initiative or preparing for a big community event. Other weeks are more structured, with regular meetings and client appointments. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, but I also try to set boundaries so I can be present for my family. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that my work is a part of who I am, and I take pride in what I do. Still, I'm always trying to find that balance between being dedicated to my job and being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Elizabeth Carlsen: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, especially since I have two young children and a demanding full-time position. That said, I do volunteer part-time at a local community center, which is more of a passion project than a second job. It's something I do in the evenings or on weekends when I can, and it's not paid work—it's more about giving back to the community that has supported me so much over the years. I think it's important to stay connected to the causes I care about, even if it's just in a small way. It also gives me a sense of purpose outside of my main job, which is something I really value. I don't know if I could handle having more than one job right now, but I'm grateful for the flexibility my current role allows me to have with my family.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how deeply my emotional well-being is connected to my ability to manage stress and maintain balance in my life. It's been a journey to recognize that my anxiety and worries aren't just personal struggles—they affect my family, my work, and even my sense of purpose. I've come to understand that setting boundaries, asking for help, and being intentional about self-care are not signs of weakness, but necessary steps to being the best version of myself for my children, my husband, and the community I serve. These reflections have also made me more aware of how my financial situation and daily responsibilities contribute to my stress, and how important it is to find ways to adapt and cope without losing sight of what truly matters. I'm grateful for the support I've received from my family and friends, and I hope that by modeling resilience and emotional honesty, I'm helping my kids build a healthier relationship with their own challenges and emotions.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Elizabeth Carlsen: In total, our household made roughly around $10,500 in the past month. Both Daniel and I work full time, and while our salaries aren't enormous, they're enough to cover our expenses, especially with the support of our savings and the fact that we both have benefits through our jobs. I think it's important to note that our income isn't just about numbers—it's about the stability it provides for our family. It allows us to live in a safe neighborhood, give our kids access to good schools, and still contribute to the community through our work and volunteer efforts. I know that for many families in our area, even this amount would be a stretch, which is why I'm so passionate about the work I do. It's not about luxury—it's about making sure we can keep showing up for each other and for the people we serve.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Elizabeth Carlsen: I've been at 'Community Roots' for about seven years now, and it's been a journey of growth, both personally and professionally. When I first started, I was still figuring out my role and how to balance my passion for advocacy with the practicalities of nonprofit work. Over time, I've come to appreciate the structure and support that the organization provides. One of the biggest benefits is the health insurance—we have access to medical, dental, and vision coverage, which is something I don't take for granted, especially given my history with migraines and anxiety. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, including vacation days, sick leave, and personal days, which is important for maintaining a healthy work-life balance. The organization also offers professional development opportunities, like workshops and conferences, which have helped me grow in my role and stay connected to the broader advocacy community. I think what stands out most is the sense of purpose that comes with the job. Even on tough days, I know that the work I'm doing matters, and that gives me a lot of motivation to keep going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Elizabeth Carlsen: My relationships at work are generally very positive and collaborative. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah Mitchell—she's been with the organization for over a decade, and she has a deep understanding of both the mission and the challenges we face. She's supportive, approachable, and always encourages us to think creatively about how we can better serve the communities we work with. I trust her judgment and feel comfortable coming to her with ideas or concerns. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We're all driven by the same values—compassion, equity, and empowerment—and that shared purpose makes it easier to work together, even when the work is tough. We have regular team meetings where we check in on each other, share updates, and sometimes just vent about the stress of the job. It's not always easy, but I think the fact that we're all in this together makes a big difference. I feel lucky to be part of a team that values both the work we do and the people we do it with.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Elizabeth Carlsen: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's definitely some flexibility depending on the needs of the organization and the families we serve. Most weeks, I have core hours from 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., but I often stay late when we're planning events or meeting with clients who have limited availability. On the other hand, I do have some flexibility in how I structure my day—sometimes I'll start a bit later if I need to drop the kids off at school, or I'll leave a little earlier if I have a family commitment. That said, there are times when the schedule can be less predictable, especially during the summer or around holidays when we're running community programs or workshops. I appreciate the flexibility it offers, but I also know that it can be challenging when it comes to balancing work and family life. It's something I've had to learn to navigate over the years, and I think it's one of the reasons I value the support of my team so much—they understand the demands of the job and the personal responsibilities that come with it.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Overall, I feel like we're in a stable financial situation, but it's definitely not without its challenges. We're able to cover our basic needs and provide for our kids, which is something I'm deeply grateful for. However, I know that the cost of living here in Cambridge is a strain on many families, and I see it every day in the work I do. There are so many people who are just trying to make ends meet, and it's heartbreaking to see how close to the edge so many of them are. I think the biggest thing that keeps me grounded is knowing that we're not in a position of extreme hardship, and that we have the ability to give back to others who are struggling. It's a delicate balance, and I'm constantly reminded that financial security is something I can't take for granted. I also know that my job and the support we receive from our community are what make this possible, and I try to be mindful of that every day.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work-life balance shape my daily experiences and long-term goals. It's interesting to look at how my bills fluctuate with the seasons and the needs of my family, and how that affects my ability to plan for the future. I've come to appreciate the small steps we take in saving, even if it's just a little each month, because it gives me a sense of security in a world that can feel unpredictable. At the same time, I'm reminded of how lucky we are compared to many others in our community who struggle to make ends meet. My job, while demanding, is also a source of purpose, and I feel grateful for the flexibility it offers, even if it sometimes makes balancing work and family life challenging. These reflections have deepened my understanding of how interconnected my financial stability, emotional well-being, and sense of responsibility to others truly are.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Elizabeth Carlsen: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a high school teacher, and he worked full time for over thirty years, which is how he was able to retire comfortably. My mother was a nurse, and she worked part-time for a while when I was younger, but she eventually went back to full-time work after I started college. I remember how hard they both worked to provide for our family, and I always felt grateful for their sacrifices. It wasn't about luxury—it was about stability, education, and making sure we had the basics. I think that's one of the reasons I chose a career in community advocacy, because I saw how much their work meant for people like us, and I wanted to give back in a similar way. I also remember how they always made time for me, even when they were busy, and that taught me the importance of balancing work and family life. It's something I try to carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Carlsen: My father was a high school teacher, and his most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and, most importantly, connecting with his students. He had a way of making even the most difficult subjects feel accessible, and he always believed that education was the key to a better life. He would stay after school to help students who were struggling, and I remember seeing him light up when a student finally understood something they had been working on for weeks. My mother was a nurse, and her most important duties were caring for her patients, making sure they were comfortable, and advocating for them when they needed it most. She had a deep sense of compassion, and I think that's what made her so good at her job. She would often come home exhausted but always made time to talk to me about her day, which taught me the value of empathy and service. Both of them worked hard, not just for us, but for the people they served—whether it was my father's students or my mother's patients. I think that's why I feel so strongly about the work I do now, because I see their influence in everything I do.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Elizabeth Carlsen: My father worked at a public high school in our town, and my mother worked at a local hospital. Both of them were employed by government or nonprofit organizations, which meant their work was more about service than profit. My father's job involved not only teaching subjects like English and history but also mentoring students, organizing school events, and being a constant presence in the lives of the kids he taught. He made sure that education wasn't just about textbooks and tests—it was about preparing students for life. My mother, on the other hand, worked in a hospital's emergency department, where she saw a wide range of patients, from the elderly to newborns. Her job required her to be on her feet all day, to think quickly, and to show compassion even in the most difficult situations. I remember her coming home with stories about the people she helped, and I think that's what made her work so meaningful. Neither of them made a lot of money, but they always made sure we had what we needed, and they taught me that work isn't just about earning a paycheck—it's about making a difference in someone else's life.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Elizabeth Carlsen: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but with a little more balance and a lot more time for the things that truly matter—like my family, my health, and the people in our community. I hope my kids are growing into compassionate, curious, and resilient individuals who feel empowered to make a difference in their own way. I also hope that the organization I work with continues to grow and have an even greater impact on the lives of immigrant and refugee families. I want to see more policies that support equity and inclusion, and I hope that my voice, along with the voices of so many others, helps shape that future. On a more personal level, I hope I'm still running, still reading, still finding joy in the little things—like the smell of fresh herbs in the garden or the sound of my kids laughing. I hope I'm not just surviving, but truly living, and that I'm able to pass on the lessons I've learned to the next generation.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Elizabeth Carlsen: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection with my family, with my community, and with the people I serve through my work. I think it's easy to get caught up in the busyness of life, but I've come to realize that the moments that matter most are the ones where I'm truly present with someone else. Whether it's my kids laughing as they play in the park, my husband and I having a quiet conversation over coffee, or sitting with a client who's just found a place to call home, those are the things that give my life meaning. I also value resilience—the ability to keep going, even when things are hard. I've seen that in my parents, in my friends, and in the people I work with every day. It's not about being perfect or having everything figured out; it's about showing up, even when it's difficult, and finding ways to support each other along the way. I hope that my children grow up knowing that the most important things in life aren't always the ones you can buy or measure—they're the ones you feel, the ones you share, and the ones that remind you that you're not alone.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how deeply my work and financial stability are connected to my sense of purpose and well-being. Talking about my income, expenses, and the structure of my job reminded me of how much I value the balance between earning a living and being present for my family. It also made me think about how lucky I am to have a job that not only pays the bills but also aligns with my values and allows me to make a difference in people's lives. I'm grateful for the benefits my job provides, like health insurance and paid time off, which give me peace of mind and the flexibility I need to manage both work and family responsibilities. It's humbling to think about how many people in our community don't have the same stability, and it reinforces my commitment to advocating for those who need it most. These reflections have deepened my appreciation for the role my job plays in my life, not just as a source of income, but as a way to contribute to something larger than myself.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just about the events and choices that shaped me, but also about the people, values, and community that have been the foundation of my life. It's humbling to see how my childhood, the support of my family, and the pivotal moments like that summer internship have all led me to where I am today—working in community advocacy, raising two children with the same values my parents instilled in me, and living in a neighborhood that reflects the diversity and resilience I admire. I've come to realize that life isn't just about the big decisions or the challenges we face, but also about the small, everyday connections—the laughter with my kids, the conversations with my husband, the moments of kindness I share with others. This reflection has reminded me of how deeply interconnected my personal story is with the stories of those around me, and how grateful I am for the path I've walked so far.
